questions.text: Excessive anxiety and worry (apprehensive expectation), occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about a number of events or activities (such as work or school performance).
Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day (as indicated by subjective account or observation).
The individual finds it difficult to control the worry.

Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by subjective report (e.g., feels sad, empty, hopeless) or observation by others (e.g., appears tearful). Note: In children and adolescents, can be irritable mood.

Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment (e.g., apparent indifference to pain/temperature, adverse response to specific sounds or textures, excessive smelling or touching of objects, visual fascination with lights or movement)
Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep).
Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s)
Often loses things necessary for tasks or activities (e.g., school materials, pencils, books, tools, wallets, keys, paperwork, eyeglasses, mobile telephones).

Is often "on the go," acting as if "driven by a motor" (e.g., is unable to be or uncomfortable being still for extended time, as in restaurants, meetings; may be experienced by others as being restless or difficult to keep up with).

Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) that arouse distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about the traumatic event(s)
Often fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes in schoolwork, at work, or during other activities (e.g., overlooks or misses details, work is inaccurate).
Markedly diminished interest or participation in significant activities, including constriction of play (child ≤6)
Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s) (may appear as play reenactment in children ≤6)
Often runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate. (Note: In adolescents or adults, may be limited to feeling restless.)
Is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli (for older adolescents and adults, may include unrelated thoughts).
Often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly.
Avoidance of or efforts to avoid people, conversations, or interpersonal situations that arouse recollections of the traumatic event(s) (child ≤6)
Persistent negative emotional state (e.g., fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame)
Irritable behavior and angry outbursts (with little or no provocation) typically expressed as verbal or physical aggression toward people or objects, including extreme temper tantrums (child ≤6)
Often fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat.
Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (e.g., happiness, satisfaction, or loving feelings)
Sleep disturbance (e.g., difficulty falling or staying asleep or restless sleep) (child ≤6)
Hypervigilance (child ≤6)
Exaggerated startle response
Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank.
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by contamination or other obsessions in obsessive-compulsive disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by the content of delusional beliefs in schizophrenia or delusional disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).?
Have these symptoms persisted for the required duration (usually > 2 weeks or 6 months depending on disorder)?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication).?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by reminders of traumatic events in posttraumatic stress disorder.?
Is it true that: The symptoms are not better explained by a dissociative disorder.?
Do you adhere to this criterion: There is clear evidence that the symptoms interfere with, or reduce the quality of, social, academic, or occupational functioning.?
Have these symptoms persisted for the required duration (usually > 2 weeks or 6 months depending on disorder)?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by gaining weight in anorexia nervosa.?
Do you adhere to this criterion: The intensity, duration, or frequency of the anxiety and worry is out of proportion to the actual likelihood or impact of the anticipated event.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by having a serious illness in illness anxiety disorder.?
Do you adhere to this criterion: The symptoms are inconsistent with developmental level and negatively impact directly on social and academic/occupational activities.?
Is it true that: The symptoms are not better explained by substance intoxication or withdrawal.?
Is it true that: The symptoms are not better explained by a mood disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by anxiety or worry about having panic attacks in panic disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by physical complaints in somatic symptom disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by perceived appearance flaws in body dysmorphic disorder.?
Is it true that: The symptoms are not better explained by an anxiety disorder.?
Do you adhere to this criterion: The anxiety, worry, or physical symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.?
Do you adhere to this criterion: The symptoms are not solely a manifestation of oppositional behavior, defiance, hostility, or failure to understand tasks or instructions.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by separation from attachment figures in separation anxiety disorder.?
Is it true that: The symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder.?
Is it true that: The disturbance is not better explained by negative evaluation in social anxiety disorder (social phobia).?
Is it true that: Several symptoms were present prior to age 12?
Is it true that: The symptoms are not better explained by a personality disorder.?
Directly experiencing the traumatic event(s) (child ≤6 years)
Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly (e.g., mind seems elsewhere, even in the absence of any obvious distraction).
Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities (e.g., has difficulty remaining focused during lectures, conversations, or lengthy reading).

Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge.
Is often forgetful in daily activities (e.g., doing chores, running errands; for older adolescents and adults, returning calls, paying bills, keeping appointments).

Often interrupts or intrudes on others (e.g., butts into conversations, games, or activities; may start using other people's things without asking or receiving permission; for adolescents and adults, may intrude into or take over what others are doing).

Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech (e.g., simple motor stereotypies, lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, idiosyncratic phrases)
